Module kivakit.configuration
Package com.telenav.kivakit.configuration.settings

Class Settings

java.lang.Object
com.telenav.kivakit.kernel.messaging.broadcasters.Multicaster
com.telenav.kivakit.kernel.messaging.repeaters.BaseRepeater
com.telenav.kivakit.configuration.settings.Settings
All Implemented Interfaces:
SettingsTrait, Receiver, Transmitter, Named, NamedObject, Broadcaster, Listener, Repeater, Transceiver, Iterable<Object>
Direct Known Subclasses:
Deployment, SettingsFolder, SettingsPackage
public class Settings extends BaseRepeater implements SettingsTrait, Named, Iterable<Object>

A registry of (untyped) user-defined settings Objects.

This class is the base class for SettingsFolder and SettingsPackage, which load settings information from .properties files in folders and packages, respectively. Settings objects are loaded when they are requested, and each .properties resource describes just one settings object. This means that a settings folder or package will often have more than one .properties resource in it, such as: 

 settings
  |── DatabaseSettings.properties
  ├── WebSettings.properties
  └── HdfsSettings.properties

This class is also the base class for Deployment, which holds settings objects relevant to a particular application or server deployment. Deployments are the most common use case for settings registries and typically they should be all that is required by an application. See Deployment for detailed usage examples.

Global Settings

The global Settings registry is the default registry returned by of(Object), and it is normally the central point of registration for an application. The global settings registry allows settings objects to be easily queried from client code anywhere.

Component Settings

A component can also have its own settings registry. This can be retrieved with of(Object), which returns the global registry by default. The Application object uses of(Object) by default to access application's settings registry.

SettingsTrait

The SettingsTrait interface provides a set of default convenience methods that can be added to any class. The Component interface in kivakit-component extends SettingsTrait to provide easy access to settings methods to all components.

How Settings Are Located

The settings*() methods can be used to locate settings objects. All settings objects are registered in the global lookup Registry, where they can be found with Registry.require*() methods. Before checking the settings registry, the settings*() methods consult the global lookup registry first. This allows settings to be overridden with a Deployments or using a command line variable, as described below. If the required settings object is not already registered, all settings objects are loaded from the specified package to provide a default object. Then, the lookup is retried and the result is returned.

Overriding Settings from the Command Line

Settings can be overridden from the command line by specifying a comma-separated folder list using KIVAKIT_SETTINGS_FOLDERS environment variable. All settings from each folder in the list will be loaded and will override the default settings that might otherwise be used. 

 java -DKIVAKIT_SETTINGS_FOLDERS=my-settings-folder [...]

Locating Configurations with the Global Registry

For convenience, each settings object is added to the global lookup. This allows clients to easily look up settings objects and not depend on where they came from. For example: 

 var serverSettings = Registry.lookup(ServerSettings.class)

Properties File Format

Properties files are of this general form:

Server1.properties

 class=com.telenav.navigation.my.application.Server$Configuration
 instance=SERVER1
 port=aws.amazon.com:7001

Here, the "class" key designates a class to instantiate (note that the nested class has to be indicated with '$' rather than '.' here). The object that is created from this class is populated with the property values by using ObjectPopulator, which automatically converts each property value into an object using the converter framework. To do this, properties in the settings object are tagged with KivaKitPropertyConverter indicating which converter the ObjectPopulator should use to convert a string value in the properties file to the corresponding object. For example, in this case the property converter for the settings class above is Port.Converter and the port property is converted to a Port object:

Server.Configuration Class

 public class Configuration
 {
     private Port port;

    @KivaKitPropertyConverter(Port.Converter.class)
     public void port( Port port)
     {
         this.port = port;
     }

    [...]
 }

The key "instance" designates which instance of settings object the *.properties* file refers to (in the event that more than one object of the same type is registered with the same registry).

Settings Registry Instances

The methods above under Global Settings will typically be enough for most applications. However, for more complex requirements, it is possible to work with individual settings registry instances. Settings objects can be registered with a Settings registry instance using these methods:

  • SettingsTrait.registerSettings(Object) - Registers the given user-defined settings object
  • SettingsTrait.registerSettings(Object, Enum) - Registers the given instance of the given user-defined settings object
  • registerSettings(Object, InstanceIdentifier) - Registers the given instance of the given user-defined settings object
  • registerAllSettingsIn(Settings) - Adds the objects in the given settings registry to this registry
  • SettingsTrait.registerAllSettingsIn(Listener, Folder) - Registers all the settings objects defined by .properties files in the given folder
  • SettingsTrait.registerAllSettingsIn(Listener, Package) - Registers all the settings objects defined by .properties files in the given package
  • SettingsTrait.registerAllSettingsIn(Listener, Class, String) - Adds the package of .properties files at the given path relative to the given class
  • SettingsTrait.registerAllSettingsIn(Listener, Folder) - Adds the folder of .properties files
  • install() - Installs the contents of this Settings into the global settings registry

Settings from a settings registry instance can be added to the global settings registry with install(). The install method is used in Deployment to install the settings objects for a server deployment in the global settings registry. See Deployment for a detailed example of how this works.

Configuration objects are loaded transparently by using the Deployment, SettingsFolder and SettingsPackage subclasses of this class. For example: 

 ConfigurationFolder.of(new Folder("development")).forEach(System.out::println);

Settings objects can then be queried by class, and with an optional Enum or InstanceIdentifier specifier in cases where more than one settings object of a given class is in use. The settings() overloaded methods return a settings object or null if no settings object can be found. The requireSettings() methods throw an exception if no settings object can be found for the given arguments:

  • SettingsTrait.hasSettings(Class) - Determines if a settings object of the given type exists
  • SettingsTrait.hasSettings(Class, Enum) - Determines if the specified instance of given settings object type exists
  • SettingsTrait.hasSettings(Class, String) - Determines if the specified instance of given settings object type exists
  • SettingsTrait.hasSettings(Class, InstanceIdentifier) - Determines if the specified instance of given settings object type exists
  • SettingsTrait.settingsRegistry() - All settings objects
  • SettingsTrait.lookupSettings(Class) - Gets the settings object of the given type
  • lookupSettings(Class, InstanceIdentifier) - Gets the specified instance of the settings object with the given type
  • SettingsTrait.lookupSettings(Class, Enum) - Gets the specified instance of the settings object with the given type

Loading Configurations as DeploymentSets

In most cases, it will not be necessary to manually add settings objects to a settings registry. They can be automatically loaded and added by using the Deployment and DeploymentSet classes and occasionally with SettingsPackage and SettingsFolder. To understand how to load and use collections of settings objects called deployments in an Application, see Deployment.

Author:
jonathanl (shibo)
